Tip_Text: "Research has shown that simply petting a dog lowers the stress hormone cortisol."
"Research shows that social interaction between people and their dogs actually increases levels of the feel-good hormone oxytocin (the same hormone that bonds mothers to babies)."

"84 percent of post-traumatic stress disorder patients paired with a service dog reported a significant reduction in symptoms, and 40 percent were able to decrease their medications, reported a recent survey."
"The American Heart Association released a research report endorsing dog ownership as a way of warding off cardiovascular disease."
The cortisol-lowering and oxytocin-boosting benefits of petting a dog has been shown to lower blood pressure.
"A 2011 study found that pet owners had better self-esteem."
"A study determined that pets provided greater social support than humans in mitigating depression."
Walk a neighbor’s dog ... or donate time at a local animal shelter—even short interactions provide enough pet exposure to reap physical, emotional, and physical health rewards.
According to Jeremy Barron, medical director at John's Hopkins, "pets are a good social catalyst for meeting people who share your animal interests."

"Over the years, research has shown that pet owners, and particularly dog owners, have greater life satisfaction, enhanced self-esteem, reduced levels of loneliness and anxiety, more ambition and more positive moods."
A study conducted regarding University students and dogs, "indicated that interacting with a pet dog considerably reduces anxiety and feelings of sadness and improves happiness scores."

Studies found that, "people with severe ambulatory disabilities (e.g., spinal cord
injuries, traumatic brain injury) who were given a service dog
showed well-being improvements (e.g., self-esteem, locus of control) within 6 months."
Dogs can help people be more physically fit, less lonely, and less fearful.
